segments.en: Numbered Discourses 10
6. Your Own Mind
54. Serenity

segments.pli: “No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paracittapariyāyakusalo hoti, atha ‘sacittapariyāyakusalo bhavissāmī’ti—
segments.en: “Mendicants, if a mendicant isn’t skilled in the ways of another’s mind, then they should train themselves: ‘I will be skilled in the ways of my own mind.’
And how is a mendicant skilled in the ways of their own mind?

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, itthī vā puriso vā daharo yuvā maṇḍanakajātiko ādāse vā parisuddhe pariyodāte acche vā udapatte sakaṃ mukhanimittaṃ paccavekkhamāno sace tattha passati rajaṃ vā aṅgaṇaṃ vā, tasseva rajassa vā aṅgaṇassa vā pahānāya vāyamati.
segments.en: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they see any dirt or blemish there, they’d try to remove it.

segments.pli: No ce tattha passati rajaṃ vā aṅgaṇaṃ vā, tenevattamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo:
segments.en: But if they don’t see any dirt or blemish there, they’re happy with that, as they’ve got all they wished for:
‘How fortunate that I’m clean!’

segments.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno paccavekkhaṇā bahukārā hoti kusalesu dhammesu:
segments.en: In the same way, checking is very helpful for a mendicant’s skillful qualities.

segments.pli: ‘lābhī nu khomhi ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, na nu khomhi lābhī ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, lābhī nu khomhi adhipaññādhammavipassanāya, na nu khomhi lābhī adhipaññādhammavipassanāyā’ti.
segments.en: ‘Do I have internal serenity of heart or not? Do I have the higher wisdom of discernment of principles or not?’

segments.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
segments.en: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:

segments.pli: ‘lābhīmhi ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, na lābhī adhipaññādhammavipassanāyā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā ajjhattaṃ cetosamathe patiṭṭhāya adhipaññādhammavipassanāya yogo karaṇīyo.
segments.en: ‘I have serenity but not discernment.’ Grounded on serenity, they should practice meditation to get discernment.

segments.pli: So aparena samayena lābhī ceva hoti ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa lābhī ca adhipaññādhammavipassanāya.
segments.en: After some time they have both serenity and discernment.

segments.pli: Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
segments.en: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:

segments.pli: ‘lābhīmhi adhipaññādhammavipassanāya, na lābhī ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā adhipaññādhammavipassanāya patiṭṭhāya ajjhattaṃ cetosamathe yogo karaṇīyo.
segments.en: ‘I have discernment but not serenity.’ Grounded on discernment, they should practice meditation to get serenity.

segments.pli: So aparena samayena lābhī ceva hoti adhipaññādhammavipassanāya lābhī ca ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa.
segments.en: After some time they have both serenity and discernment.

segments.pli: Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
segments.en: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:

segments.pli: ‘na lābhī ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, na lābhī adhipaññādhammavipassanāyā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā tesaṃyeva kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭilābhāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
segments.en: ‘I have neither serenity nor discernment.’ In order to get those skillful qualities, they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ādittacelo vā ādittasīso vā.
segments.en: Suppose your clothes or head were on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.

segments.pli: Tasseva celassa vā sīsassa vā nibbāpanāya adhimattaṃ chandañca vāyāmañca ussāhañca ussoḷhiñca appaṭivāniñca satiñca sampajaññañca kareyya.
Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tena bhikkhunā tesaṃyeva kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭilābhāya adhimatto chando ca vāyāmo ca ussāho ca ussoḷhī ca appaṭivānī ca sati ca sampajaññañca karaṇīyaṃ.
segments.en: In the same way, in order to get those skillful qualities, that person should apply outstanding enthusiasm …

segments.pli: So aparena samayena lābhī ceva hoti ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa lābhī ca adhipaññādhammavipassanāya.
segments.en: After some time they have both serenity and discernment.

segments.pli: Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṃ jānāti:
segments.en: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:

segments.pli: ‘lābhīmhi ajjhattaṃ cetosamathassa, lābhī adhipaññādhammavipassanāyā’ti, tena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā tesuyeva kusalesu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya uttari āsavānaṃ khayāya yogo karaṇīyo.
segments.en: ‘I have both serenity and discernment.’ Grounded on those skillful qualities, they should practice meditation further to end the defilements.
I say that there are two kinds of robes:
those you should wear, and those you shouldn’t wear.
I say that there are two kinds of almsfood:
that which you should eat, and that which you shouldn’t eat.
I say that there are two kinds of lodging:
those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.
I say that there are two kinds of market town:
those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.
I say that there are two kinds of country:
those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.
I say that there are two kinds of people:
those you should frequent, and those you shouldn’t frequent.
‘I say that there are two kinds of robes:
those you should wear, and those you shouldn’t wear.’

segments.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
segments.en: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
Take a robe of which you know this:

segments.pli: ‘idaṃ kho me cīvaraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpaṃ cīvaraṃ na sevitabbaṃ.
segments.en: ‘When I wear this robe, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not wear that kind of robe.
Take a robe of which you know this:

segments.pli: ‘idaṃ kho me cīvaraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpaṃ cīvaraṃ sevitabbaṃ.

those you should wear, and those you shouldn’t wear.’

that which you should eat, and that which you shouldn’t eat.’

sections.title: “Mendicants, if a mendicant isn’t skilled in the ways…

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha teaches that, if you can’t read anyone else’s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection. Includes a teaching on various things that should or should not be cultivated.
